title: Wednesday, 28th November 2018
bodyHTML:
11:07 am
BE11:08am

Okay, time to push the rock back up the hill. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's whatever with the whatever.

Mouselet Good morning Bryce. Thank you for continuing in your Sisyphean efforts.
BE11:09am

How can we make this next hour valuable? Corporate's pretty thin .....

FATDAZ Good morning Bryce and fellow ROTR members
Excel Developer Leveraged Loans?
BE11:09am

Politics is equally thin ......

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Excel Developer @Bryce: I though you hated Brexit talk.
jaws gm
Mouselet Does Hammond also have comments about the faith of the pontiff and the defecatory habits of bears?
BE11:10am

Yep, well, sort of.

Soundbuy Morning
BE11:10am

“If you look at this purely from the economic point of view, there will be a cost to leaving the EU because there will be impediments to trade,” Mr Hammond told the BBC’s Today programme.

jaws JE some rumors in paper on that thin news today
11:11 am
BE11:11am

"If you look at this purely from the economic point of view" is the parachute phrase here. Brexiteers will say it's about .... whatever it's about ..... sovereignty or liberty or xenophobia or magic unicorns or whatever.

RiskyBoy Shire down after former Takeda Chairman comments? Has anyone estimated % probability of deal not going through?
Soundbuy If corporate's a tad thin, my usual request for runners and riders for next FTSE rejig would be appreciated................and associated demand etc.....
BE11:12am

It's a very well turned phrase by Hammond, aimed straight down the middle.

BE11:13am

Anyway, let's get out of that rut and find another one to chuck ourselves into.

11:13 am
undefined
Mouselet I don't think anyone doubts the political competence of Hammond, which is kind of refreshing given the rest of the Cabinet!
Excel Developer @Bryce: Nobody says to USA, congrats on NAFTA but why not go further and have EMU, a supreme court above SCOTUS and unfettered immigration across Mex USA border. But in theory that would deliver higher growth. So USA is leaving money on the table to be an independent country. So why not UK the same?
BE11:14am

Shire's interesting, at the margin.

Mouselet I'm assuming the house-builders are down because of the reports that mortgage companies are getting worse at assessing affordability.
Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 4,474, down 71 (-1.56%), High: 4,541, Low: 4,450, Volume: 1.06m
Pharma @Mouselet - Hammond's political competence is very much dependent on your point of view.
Mouselet I often say to USA that freedom of movement across NAFTA and an intention to have the southern border of NAFTA be in Tierra del Fuego in the longest term is their obvious next step - why would it not be - but it appears not completely politically acceptable.
Pharma "one's", I should say
11:15 am
BE11:15am

ADRs were much, much lower overnight on the stuff about Takeda Pharmaceutical's former chairman Kunio Takeda saying he doesn't like the deal.

SupposeToBeWorking... Morning all
BE11:16am

A story the FT ran on November 16: https://www.ft.com...-a34c-663b3f553b35

qwerty TRG shares down 10%. Any news from the front? Meeting was 9.30.
Flaneur " .... whatever it's about ....." its about slapping the establishment for using public fund to bail out banks, Bryce.A sort of 'if we're going down, we're taking you with us' from the British public.
Mouselet Because not bailing out banks would have made everyone so much happier?
BE11:17am

Yesterday's reaction was in response to Nikkei reporting the same story, but with more specific citing.

Mouselet Put the insured deposit limit back down to 'first £2k plus 90% of the next £18k' and see what happens?
11:18 am
BE11:18am

(@Flaneur: I don't remember that being a key campaign platform in June 2016. I do remember lots of posters with queues of people though. Perhaps my memory's just faulty.)

Tom Dalgleish FT is the naughty child of Nikkei
Pharma Further Reading had a Times story about a new mortgage "time-bomb", seemingly on the basis that 100% mortgages and high income multiples were returning. I'd have thought the revised BoE rules on average loan books put that in scaremongering territory. Potentially bad for the individuals concerned, but not a systemic risk.
BE11:19am

.... in terms of whether it changes anything .......... we don't know! Because Japan's difficult to understand from afar.

Mouselet We *know* that the individuals concerned make loud noises and cause systemic political risk, that's exactly Flaneur's point
BE11:19am

FWIW, UBS reckons the vote'll go through easy.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

We expect 85-90% to vote for the deal at the EGM

BE11:20am

That's off the back of a survey of 74 institutions.

CS1 Grim article by Alex Barker in the FT today re Brexit
Flaneur (@BE - maybe you should read back over the last 10 years of comments on ML/AV.But like Mr Lionels pre-ref polling results, the FT chose to ignore that too...)
BE11:20am

51% of respondents were very bullish or bullish on Takeda Pharma’s shares. Interestingly, responses differed by investor type, with 63% of hedge funds answering positively while 36% of other investors were positive. No major regional differences were observed. No respondents indicated they were “very bearish”.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

66% of respondents answered that approval at the EGM (extraordinary general meeting) is the most important, and it is the main focus for investors. On the other hand, opinion on the next most important issue was divided between flowback of new shares and dividends. We think Takeda may need to address investor scepticism on dividends. It was slightly surprising to us that investors were less interested in margin expansion and management stability. Investors could be optimistic on Takeda Pharma’s execution of its Global OPEX program. It is good news that Takeda Pharma’s management is regarded as stable.

FATDAZ @pharma High LTV and high multiples are less of an issue if rates are fixed over the whole term ie 25 or 30 years not really sure why we dont offer loans like that (I do know why really - banks make loads of money out switchers and refinancing etc via fees)
Pharma Just saying that improved regulation has fixed that potential source of grief. No doubt banks will find other ways to fail.
undefined
Mouselet Because a 30-year fixed mortgage has to be fixed at 5% or so and looks bad as a headline rate?
BE11:23am

So, that's the arbs covered. What else can we do?

Excel Developer @fatdaz: and less mortgage securitization to offload 30 year fixed. if you were thinking of USA.
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Revisit Thomas Cook maybe?

DJ FeverTree been v weak recently?
Thomas Cook Group plc (TCG:LSE): Last: 35.46, down 2.1 (-5.60%), High: 37.90, Low: 33.50, Volume: 16.44m
RiskyBoy thanks for Shire.
Mouselet on the shoeshine-boy scale, the fact that googling the 30 year bond rate gets me four separate advertisers trying to sell high-yield corporate bonds to the uninformed doesn't seem totally positive
rw42 Do think it'll get interesting with H2B in 5 years time - there's a lot of stuff about making sure you can theoretically repay the govt loan, but nothing that actually forces you to set money aside for it!
BE11:24am

Market cap very close to going sub £500m now. I think it's already been overtaken by Wagamama on today values.

FATDAZ @Pharma Morgan Stanley recently described RBS as 'gold plated' or similar in respect of its ability to generate capital and return it to share holders so thats one less to worry about
11:24 am
BE11:24am

And I'm not sure we fully got across what a shambles yesterday was.

Pharma @FATDAZ I prefer the system here, where you can choose from variable to 10+ year fixes, to the US system where maturity risk is hidden in a complex system of "points" (additional interest depending on how flexible you want the deal to be in x-years time).
BE11:26am

To recap, the new FD has come in and decided that a bunch of stuff previously considered (but not called) exceptionals should be taken through the P&L. Why? We don't know.

FATDAZ @mouslet @excel I was thinking of the USA and as to 5% rate UK 30 yer gilt yields are a smidge over 2% currently so suspect it could be offered cheaper if the will was there
BE11:27am

And credit headroom's fine, apparently, in spite of Thomas Cook having to renegotiate with lenders and cancel its dividend to save just £6m.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

What happens in hard Brexit? Dunno.

BE11:28am

What actually is the working capital position and liquidity headroom? Dunno.

BE11:29am

Can we get some impression of free cashflow without the exceptionals that were never called exceptionals, and are now not even not-exceptionals? Nope.

FATDAZ @Pharma longer the better as it allows you to budget with certainty at least on the outgoing side - to use trading analogy it is unexpected or unforeseen margin calls that knock people out of their positions and in turn adding to volatility
11:29 am
BE11:29am

It's all a bit unclear, to summarise. Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:30am

We suspend our price target, given the very wide risk-reward spread (20p - 130p), and therefore move our rating to Equalweight.

Curious Thoughts on Horlicks?
BE11:30am

Current trading looks weak for Winter FY18/19 (Tour Operator 65% booked with volumes -3% and average selling price -1%), and the company noted a mixed start to Summer 2019. We estimate the margin difference between early and late holidays is £80-90, so a say 5% shift from early to late bookings could reduce average yields by £4, and given EBIT / holiday is only ~£20 for the major tour operators, a 5% shift in booking patterns can lead to a 20% profit headwind. Looking to 2019 we could see another late booking year, with Brexit causing not only consumer uncertainty but also possibly 'scare stories' in the media about travel delays, visa issues, and increasing travel expenses.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Course, when you get to the cashflow line it's just blindfold darts stuff.

BE11:32am

Our FCF downgrade is more significant than our EPS downgrade, reflecting higher than expected cash exceptionals and capex, and a working capital inflow seems less likely given the ongoing shift to later booking. We now forecast £21m FCF for FY19e vs £124m previously (and our £213m forecast at the start of the year). The dividend suspension is a surprise, as it is only provides a £9m cash saving. This could conceivably be seen as a sign of tightening liquidity, though the company
says it has plenty of headroom. The company also said it would not provide details on its debt covenants, but that it had approached its finance partners and received support. There are no debt maturities before 2022. We also note the increase in the company's trade payables and receivables have contributed to a ~£540m working capital inflow in the last 5 years (up until FY17, pending FY18's annual report being published), and any move back in payable days could reverse some of this. Clarity on these areas would be welcome.

FATDAZ WOW just £20 of ebit per holiday that leaves very little wiggle room
AlsoCurious Thoughts on RPC?
Soundbuy Wasn't OTB today?
Tom Dalgleish @Fat, just a terrible business, hot weather notwithstanding
BE11:33am

We might get some clarity on some of this stuff tomorrow, assuming Thomas Cook itself has clarity. Though the impression given so far isn't promising.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

With more upside to our bull case than our bear case, the shares already seem to be pricing in a lot of risk and appear attractive. But we have little confidence in our forecasts, and less so in our FCF forecasts. Put another way, on our below consensus forecasts the FY19 P/E of 4.6x looks attractive, but the 27x FCF less so.

undefined
Pharma @FATDAZ, if you think that, there are long fixed loans available here. Would have been a bad call in the recent past, with interest rates falling and staying low (someone who took out a 30 year loan in 2008 would still have 20 years to go).
BE11:34am

As for On The Beach, they're in line.

FATDAZ @be having heard that £20 stat and thinking of all the variables that TCG is exposed to I would guess FCF is flat to negative just saying
11:34 am
On The Beach Group PLC (OTB:LSE): Last: 409.00, up 7 (+1.74%), High: 423.00, Low: 398.50, Volume: 1.36m
Mouselet pharma: remember the mis-selling put option
BE11:35am

And of course it's a completely different model to Thomas Cook ... low opex, low inventories, most of the cash burn is on terrible aim-low adverts.

Mouselet ie long fixed loans with any plausible early-repayment penalty are pretty clearly not an object that can be sold to unsophisticated buyers without very substantial risk of having a court repudiate them
Pharma @Mouselet - and perhaps that's why banks don't push them here...
BE11:36am

Current trading guidance is pretty positive, with the caveat that nearly no one books a summer holiday in November.

Excel Developer I found an Oil VIX btw a propos Monday's session, https://www.investing.com/indices/cboe-crude-oil-volatility
Soundbuy OTB - demoted at reshuffle perhaps?
rw42 Wouldn't go longer than a 5 year fix as there's early repayment fees if you want to do something silly like sell it and move on, regardless of the interest rate it went for!
11:36 am
BE11:36am

Who can summarise here? Peel Hunt?

BE11:36am

For FY19 so far, management reports strong early trading and a
performance in line with its expectations. FY18 results were solid
despite the impact of the heatwave. Key KPIs (branded share of
traffic, repeat purchase rate, proportion of exclusive hotels) all
continue to make progress and show that the strategy is on track.

Soundbuy Out of the FTSE250 that is............
qwerty TRG. Looks like the turkeys voted for Christmas! 60% for 40% against.
FATDAZ @Pharma re duration yes they would but they would k also now what one of their largest monthly bills would be for the duration of the loan I remember my house owning colleagues in 1992 when UK bases rates touched 15% they were not good
BE11:37am

The heatwave last summer was difficult for holiday companies as consumers stayed home or booked late. Despite this, in H218, On the Beach managed to grow UK revenue slightly and increase revenue after marketing costs by 14%. Full-year marketing/revenue fell to 42% (from 45%), partly as a function of “branded traffic” rising to 64% (cf 59%) and repeat purchases increasing 14%.

GBKrona Any views on AJBell IPO pricing please? Looks quite rich...
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Group revenue was £104m up 25% (up 9% excluding the contribution from
Classic). International revenue fell slightly, to £1.6m, as a result of a very weak summer. Group EBITDA was £36.8m, up 18%. Core UK EBITDA was
£37.9m up 14%. Adjusted PBT was £33.6m, up 18%, adjusted EPS was
21.2p up 21% and the full-year DPS was 3.3p, up 18%.

Cash generation and a cash pile. On the Beach continued to be highly cash generative in FY18 with adjusted operating cash conversion of 90%. Classic was acquired with very material working capital with the result that, despite the £20m headline price, the acquisition resulted in a modest net cash inflow. Year-end company cash was £47m, up from £33m at the end of FY17.

BE11:38am

Brexit, tho. Always Brexit.

BE11:38am

Lowering forecasts to reflect Brexit risk. We have cut our forecasts (FY19E
EPS by 3%, FY20E by 8%). This is the net effect of several factors: lowering
UK forecasts in light of possible Brexit impacts; lower forecast losses from
International; and higher profits from the Classic acquisition, which appears to be performing well as part of On the Beach.

Excel Developer @fatdaz: "MLR 15% .. anyone wanna buy a house?" ah Black Wednesday.
11:38 am
BE11:38am

Our price target reduction, to 550p from 650p, largely reflects the de-rating of the market, and technology shares in particular since we last set a target. In addition, the progress of Brexit remains highly uncertain with the potential to disrupt travel bookings and justifies greater caution over travel companies.

undefined
Upaswellasdown Any instant insight on RTN please. Seems a clearer margin in favour than was predicted in the ST
Excel Developer Black Wednesday, 26 years ago, crikey.
FATDAZ @GBK timing seems odd to me more than anything else with all the uncertainty over brexit and access to European markets etc
FATDAZ @excel yes it was but I can still remember it clearly
Pharma @FATDAZ - it's tricky, as it individualises risk. Your friends would have been better off with fixed rates, but anyone buying or remortgaging in 1992 would have been properly stuffed.I've always had the suspicion that variable rates makes the economy more sensitive to BoE interventions, so that in theory fewer/smaller interest rate changes are needed.

qwerty TRG aka RTN. With 40% voting against there will be a big overhang once the Rights completes!

I suppose I was being idealistic and thinking more home ownership than gaming interest rates over 25 years though of course you face that same game of Russian roulette later in life with pension annuity rates :(
CS1 wasn't it then George Soros made his fortune, shorting sterling

Excel Developer guys, we ought to at least attempt to tie in these comments to what Bryce is writing on the left. #AJBell, is there a prospective dividend yield and divi cover?

Are we able to argue yet that the FCA's ban on exit fees and so on was completely counterproductive as it seems only to have allowed the top five fund supermarkets to consolidate their positions and generate cartel-like margins?
